comments.commentBody: President Obama's ban on drilling is a welcome move -- even more welcome would be a federal mandate and bully pulpit campaign for conservation. Whatever happened to the idea of conservation, anyway? The US consumes per capita more than twice the EU, but do we really live better? No -- much of our economy is premised on wasteful consumption. When will we hear some of our "thought leaders" sound the alarm on wasteful consumption? There was a time when frugality and prudence were virtues; now, our consumer society has made these virtues into sins. It's a perverse state of affairs.

If putting fragile and ecological areas off limits to drilling is a threat to national security per the API, then why did the API, the GOP congress and the oil industry in general push to lift the oil export embargo in Dec. 2015?

Harold Hamm, CEO of Continental Resources, and Trump advisor, was asked that very question in a Bloomberg interview and he couldn't answer it. Likewise, he stated in the same interview that he hoped OPEC would be able to come to an agreement to cut production. I thought that a rather incredible statement for someone advising the President Elect. It certainly helps Continental but not the American consumer.

Tough conditions and low crude prices conspired to make the Arctic prospects for oil production dubious. Good for now. Local Alaskan native communities, not the State of Alaska delegation, have been given a well-deserved reprive. Let's use this haitus to move past our collective dependence on crude to not only advance other sustainable energy sources, but to build stronger political clout for the Alaskan native communities, who are already one of the world's groups already being impacted by global climate change.  If, and only if, future oil extraction is considered (which it will) it should be at the pleasure of the local inhabitants and not multinational corporations. And we need to help the greater State of Alaska to rehabilitate from their addiction.

Here's what I think everyone is missing. The next administration is going to simply frame this issue as a project that creates more jobs. The is a lose lose proposition for the Democrats who oppose this. In the current  economic and political climate if the debate is Jobs vs Environment...then jobs will win hands down...every time. Trump will argue oil drilling technology has improved over the years reducing the impact of the wells on the environment....which is true. The biggest piece of evidence supporting this is it's already being done in other parts of Alaska. Animals and oil drilling have coexisted for years all over the northern parts of Alaska.  While oil from Arctic Circle might take a couple of years to get online, the job creation and effect on the economy would be almost instantaneous, as infrastructure and development activity could start immediately, sending billions to the federal government and employing thousands of people. President Obama's symbolic gesture is admirable, but will not last one day past January 20th 2017.

A permanent drilling ban can only be described as "blindly stupid".

Norway has been drilling in the North Sea, a sensitive fishing area, for decades now, with no adverse affects to be found. I have no doubt that Obama, had he had the opportunity 30 years ago, would have put a "permanent ban" on drilling in the North Sea.

What is so obviously stupid is the "permanence" of the ban. Drilling has made incredible progress over the past decades. Twenty years ago, no one could even imagine what is normal today. There is no reason to believe we can never drill safely in the arctic.

So should we be careful about drilling in the arctic? Of course! Are we capable of drilling safely now? Probably, but if we are not, it is quite likely that we will soon be.

A permanent ban is quite literally stupidity put into policy.

Drilling in the Gulf of Mexico didn't turn out so well for BP, sealife, coasts, or the local fishing economy.

There is reason to believe that an accident like that could happen on any drilling platform, though that accident was the perfect storm of arrogance and corporate greed.
You could also call this one last reminder on why Trump won.
